ISO-25010.description: degree to which the code reflects the quality properties outlined in the ISO 25010:2011 software product quality model

Safety.description: degree to which the code cannot cause harm to individuals, damage to the product or industrial process, or adverse impacts to the environment.

Design-level Errors.description: degree to which the code is vulnerable, from both a hardware and a software level

Reliability.name: Reliability
Reliability.description:
From McCall: Extent to which a program satisfies its specifications and fulfills the user’s mission objectives (sub-characteristicof product operation)
 From ISO 25010: Degree to which a system, product or component performs specified functions under specified conditions for a specified period of time. Sub-characteristic maturity: Degree to which a system, product or component meets needs for reliability under normal operation.

Efficiency.name: Efficiency
Efficiency.description:
From McCall: The amount of computing resources and code required by a program to perform a function sub-characteristic of product operation)
 From ISO 25010: Performance relative to the amount of resources used under stated conditions. Sub-characteristic Time behavior: Degree to which the response and processing times and throughput rates of a product or system, when performing its functions, meet requirements.

Maintainability.name: Maintainability
Maintainability.description:
From McCall: Effort required to locate and fix an error in an operational program (subcharacteristic of product revision)
 From ISO 25010: Degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which a product or system can be modified to improve it

Reusability.name: Reusability
Reusability.description:
Extent to which a program can be used in other applications – related to the packaging and scope of the functions that programs perform. 
 From ISO 25010: Reusability: Degree to which a system or computer program is composed of discrete components such that a change to one component has minimal impact on other components. Modularity: Degree to which a system or computer program is composed of discrete components such that a change to one component has minimal impact on other components.

Testability.name: Testability
Testability.description:
Effort required to test a program to ensure it performs its intended function. 
 From ISO 25010: Degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which test criteria can be established for a system, product or component and tests can be performed to determine whether those criteria have been met. (subcharacteristic of maintainability)

Number of steps, transitions, branches i.name: Number of steps, transitions, branches in SFC
Number of steps, transitions, branches i.description: Number of steps, transitions, branches in SFC

Coupling of objects to the environment.name: Coupling of objects to the environment
Coupling of objects to the environment.description: Coupling of objects to the environment

Complexity and length of source code.name: Complexity and length of source code
Complexity and length of source code.description: Complexity and length of source code

Direct data exchange between POUs via ca.name: Direct data exchange between POUs via calls
Direct data exchange between POUs via ca.description: Direct data exchange between POUs via calls

Ingoing direct data exchange between POU.name: Ingoing direct data exchange between POUs via calls
Ingoing direct data exchange between POU.description: Ingoing direct data exchange between POUs via calls

SA0001: Unreachable code.description: Detects lines of code that are not executed, for example due to a RETURN or CONTINUE statement

SA0002: Empty objects.description: Detects POUs, GVLs, data type declarations, or interfaces that do not contain any code

SA0003: Empty statements.description: Detects lines of code that have a semicolon (;) but not a statement

SA0004: Multiple write access on output.description: Detects outputs which are written to more than one location.

SA0005: Invalid addresses and data types.description: Detects invalid addresses and data type specifications. Valid size prefixes in addresses: X for BOOL B for 1-byte data types, W for 2-byte data types, and D for 4-byte data types.

SA0006: Write access from several tasks.description: Detects variables which are written to by more than one task.

SA0007: Address operator on constants.description: Detects lines of code where the operator ADR is applied for a constant

SA0008: Check subrange types.description: Detects out-of-range violations of subrange types. Assigned literals are already checked by the compiler. When constants are assigned, then the values must be within the defined range. When variables are assigned, then the data types must be identical.

SA0009: Unused return values.description: Detects function, method and property calls in which the return value is not used

SA0010: Arrays with only one component.description: Detects arrays with only one element

SA0011: Useless declarations.description: Detects structures or enumerations with only one component

SA0012: Variable which could be declared.description: Detects variables that are not accessed with write permission and therefore could be declared as constants

SA0013: Declarations with the same varia.description: Detects variables with names that are already used by other variables (for example, global and local variables with the same name). Also detects variables with names of functions, actions, methods, or properties which are used in the same access scope. Variables are also detected that are declared in a GVL in the Devices view or in the POUs pool. For this, however, the GVL of the POUs view have to be used in the application program.

SA0014: Assignment of instances.description: Detects assignments to function block instances. In the case of instances with pointer or reference variables, these assignments are potentially risky.

SA0015: Access to global data via FB_Ini.description: Detects the access of a function block to global variables by means of the method FB_Init. The value of this variable depends on the order of initializations.

SA0016: Gaps in structures.description: Detects gaps in structures or function blocks that are caused by the alignment requirements of the currently set target system. If possible, you should remove the gaps by resorting the structure elements or filling them with a dummy element. If this is not possible, then you can deactivate the rule for the affected structures by means of the analysis pragma.

SA0017: Non-regular assignments.description: Detects assignments to pointers that are neither addresses (ADR operator, pointer variables) nor constants 0

SA0018: Unusual bit access.description: Detects bit access to signed variables. However, the IEC 61131-3 standard permits only bit access and bit shift operations on bit fields. See also the strict rules SA0147 and SA0148.

SA0020: Possibly assignment of truncated.description: Detects operations on integer variables for which a truncated value could be assigned to a REAL data type variable

SA0021: Transporting the address of a te.description: Detects address assignments of temporary variables (on the stack) to non-temporary variables

SA0022: (Possibly) unassigned return val.description: Detects all functions and methods that include an execution thread without an assignment to the return value

SA0023: Complex return values.description: Determines complex return values that cannot be returned with a simple registry copy of the processor. This includes structures, arrays, and return values of type STRING (regardless of the size of the used memory).

SA0025: Unqualified enumeration constant.description: Detects enumeration constants for which a qualified name does not prepend the enumeration

SA0026: Possible truncated strings.description: Detects string assignments and string initializations that do not use sufficient string length

SA0027: Multiple uses of identifiers.description: Detects multiple uses of a name/identifier for a variable or an object (POU) within the scope of a project. In the case of enumerations, the qualified name is taken into account.

SA0028: Overlapping memory areas.description: Detects the lines of code where two or more variables reserve the same memory.

SA0029: Notation in code different to de.description: Detects the code locations where the notation of an identifier is different from the notation in its declaration

SA0031: Unused signatures.description: Detects programs, function blocks, functions, data types, interfaces, methods, properties, and actions that are not called within the compiled program code

SA0032: Unused enumeration constants.description: Detects enumeration constants that are not used in the compiled program code

SA0033: Unused variables.description: Detects variables that are declared but not used within the compiled program code

SA0034: Enumerations with incorrect assi.description: Detects values that are assigned to an enumeration variable. Only defined enumeration constants of an enumeration variable are permitted to be assigned.

SA0035: Unused input variables.description: Detects input variables that are not used by any function block instance

SA0036: Unused output variables.description: Detects the output variables of functions and function blocks which are not assigned within the respective function or function block.

SA0037: Write access to input variable.description: Detects input variables (VAR_INPUT) that are accessed with write permission within the POU

SA0038: Read access to output variable.description: Detects output variables (VAR_OUTPUT) that are accessed with read permission within the POU

SA0039: Possible null-pointer deferences.description: Detects code locations where a null pointer is possibly dereferenced

SA0040: Possible division by zero.description: Detects code locations where there is possible division by zero

SA0041: Detect possible loop invariant c.description: Detects assignments in loops that calculate the same value for each loop cycle. These lines of code could possibly be inserted outside of the loop.

SA0042: Usage of different access paths.description: Detects the usage of different access paths for the same variable

SA0043: Use of a global variable in only.description: Detects the use of a global variable in only a single POU

SA0044: Declarations with reference to i.description: Detects declarations with REFERENCE TO interfaces and declarations of VAR_IN_OUT variables with interfaces (implicitly implemented by means of REFERENCE TO)

SA0046: Possible use of not initialised.description: Detects the use of interfaces that were not initialized before being used

SA0047: Accesses to direct address.description: Detects direct address access in the implementation code

SA0048: AT-declarations on direct addres.description: Detects AT declarations on direct addresses

SA0051: Comparison operations on BOOL va.description: Detects comparison operations on variables of type BOOL

SA0052: Unusual shift operation.description: Detects shift operations (bit shift) on signed variables. In the case of shift operations on bit field data types (Byte, DWORD, LWORD, WORD), an error is not reported.

SA0053: Too big bitwise shift.description: Detects whether or not the data type width of the operand has been exceeded in the case of a bitwise shift (bit shift) of operands

SA0054: Comparisons of REAL/LREAL for eq.description: Detects whether or not the comparison operators = (equality) and <> (inequality) compare the operands of type REAL or LREAL.

SA0055: Unnecessary comparisons of unsig.description: Detects unnecessary comparisons with unsigned operands. An unsigned data type is never less than zero. This can be used as a sign check.

SA0056: Constant out of valid range.description: Detects literals (constants) outside of the valid range of the operator

SA0057: Possible loss of decimal places.description: Detects statements with possible loss of decimal places

SA0058: Operations on enumeration variab.description: Detects operations on variables of the enumeration data type Assignments are permitted.

SA0059: Comparison operations always ret.description: Detects comparisons with literals that always have the result TRUE or FALSE, and can already be processed during at the compile.

SA0060: Zero used as invalid operand.description: Detects operations where an operand with the value
causes an invalid or a nonsense operation

SA0061: Unusual operation on pointer.description: Detects operations one variables of type POINTER TO which are not = (equality), <> (inequality), + (addition), or ADR.

SA0062: Uses of TRUE or FALSE in express.description: Detects the use of the literals TRUE or FALSE in expressions

SA0063: Possibly not 16-bit-compatible o.description: Detects 16-bit operations with temporary results. Background: On 16-bit systems, 32-bit temporary results can be truncated. Example: (int+10) can exceed 16 bits.

SA0065: Incorrect pointer addition to ba.description: Detects pointer additions for which the value to be added does not match the base size of the pointer. Only literals of the base size can be added. Also multiplication products of the base size cannot be added.

SA0066: Uses of temporary results.description: Detects the use of temporary results in statements with a data type that is less than the registry size. The implicit cast in this case may lead to unwanted results.

SA0072: Invalid uses of counter variable.description: Detects the use of a counter variable in a FOR loop

SA0073: Uses of inadequate counter varia.description: Detects the use of non-temporary variables in FOR loops.

SA0075: Missing ELSE.description: Detects CASE statements without an ELSE branch

SA0076: Missing enumeration constant.description: Detects whether or not an enumeration variable is used as a condition and not all enumeration values are treated as CASE branches

SA0077: Type mismatches with CASE expres.description: Detects code locations where the data type of a condition does not match that of the CASE branch

SA0078: Missing CASE branches.description: Detects CASE statements without CASE branches and only one ELSE statement

SA0080: Loop index variable for array in.description: Detects the FOR statements where the index variable is used to access an array index and exceeds the range of the array index

SA0081: Upper border is not a constant.description: Detects the FOR statements where the upper bound is not defined with a constant value

SA0090: Return statement before end of f.description: Detects whether or not the RETURN statement is not the last statement in a function, method, property, or program.

SA0095: Assignments in conditions.description: Detects assignments in conditions of IF, CASE, or REPEAT constructs

SA0100: Variables greater than <n> bytes.description: Detects variables that use more than n bytes, where n is defined by the current configuration. Default value: 1024 bytes. The value can be changed by double-clicking the line.

SA0101: Names with invalid length.description: Detects names with invalid lengths. In the Project Settings, double-click the rule entry to open a dialog where you can define the length of the name and define any exception.

A0102: Access to program/fb variables fr.description: Detects external access to local variables of programs or function blocks.

SA0103: Concurrent access on not atomic.description: Detects whether or not non-atomic variables (for example, with data type STRING, WSTRING, ARRAY, STRUCT, FB instances, 64-bit data types) are used in more than one task

SA0105: Multiple instance calls.description: Detects the instances of function blocks that are called multiple times. To do this, the function blocks haves to be marked with the pragma {attribute 'analysis:report-multiple-instance-calls'}.

SA0106: Virtual method calls in FB_INIT.description: Detects method calls in the FB_Init method of a base function block, which are overwritten by a function block derived from a base function block

SA0107: Missing formal parameters.description: Detects whether or not formal parameters are missing

SA0111: Pointer variables.description: Detects variables of type POINTER TO

SA0112: Reference variables.description: Detects variables of type REFERENCE TO

SA0115: Variables with data type UNION.description: Detects declarations of a UNION data type and variable declarations of the UNION type

SA0117: Variables with data type BIT.description: Detects variable declarations of data type BIT (possible within structure definitions)

SA0118: Initialisations not using consta.description: Detects initializations that do not assign constants

SA0119:Object-oriented features.description: Detects the use of object-oriented features, such as function block declarations with EXTENDS and IMPLEMENTS, or property and interface declarations. This rule is useful when you write code that is intended to be ported to other IEC 61131-3-compliant systems.

SA0121: Missing 'VAR_EXTERNAL' declarati.description: Detects the use of a global variable in function blocks without them being declared there as VAR_EXTERNAL

SA0122: Array index defined as expressio.description: Detects the use of expressions in the declaration of array indexes

SA0123: Usages of INI, ADR or BITADR.description: Detects the use of the CODESYS Static Analysis-specific operators INI, ADR, and BITADR.

SA0124: Pointer dereferences in declarat.description: Detects pointer dereferences that are used for initialization in the declaration part

SA0125: References in initializations.description: Detects reference variables that are used for initialization in the declaration part

SA0130: Implicit expanding conversions.description: Detects implicit conversions from smaller data types to larger data types

SA0131: Implicit narrowing conversions.description: Detects implicit conversions from larger data types to smaller data types

SA0132: Implicit signed/unsigned convers.description: Detects implicit conversions from signed data types to unsigned data types or the other way around.

SA0133: Explicit narrowing conversions.description: Detects explicit conversions from a larger data type to a smaller data type

SA0134: Explicit signed/unsigned convers.description: Detects explicit conversions from signed data types to unsigned data types and the other way around

SA0145: Possible use of not initialised.description: Detects any reference variables that may not be initialized before use and are not checked by the operator __ISVALIDREF. This rule is applied in the implementation part of POUs. For the declaration, there is rule SA0124.

SA0147: Unusual shift operation - strict.description: Detects bit shift operations that are not made to bit field data types (BYTE, WORD, DWORD, LWORD)

SA0148: Unusual bit access - strict.description: Detects bit access that is not made to bit field data types (BYTE, WORD, DWORD, and LWORD). The IEC 61131-3 standard permits only bit access to bit field data types. However, the CODESYS compiler also permits bit access to unsigned data types.

SA0150: Violations of lower or upper lim.description: Detects the POUs that violate the activated metrics at the lower or upper limits

SA0160: Recursive calls.description: Detects recursive calls in actions, methods, and properties of function blocks. Also detects possible recursions from virtual function calls and interface calls.

SA0161: Unpacked structure in packed str.description: Detects unpacked structures that are used in packed structures

SA0162: Missing comments.description: Detects uncommented locations in the program

SA0164: Multiline comments.description: Detects multiline comments that are coded as (* comment *). Only single-line comments that are coded as // comment are permitted.

SA0165: Tasks calling other POUs than pr.description: Detects tasks that call function blocks or functions instead of a program

SA0166: Max. number of input/output/in-o.description: Detects whether or not a defined number of input variables (VAR_INPUT), output variables (VAR_OUTPUT) or VAR_IN_OUT variables is exceeded in a POU. In the Project Settings, double-click the rule entry to open a dialog where you define the maximum number.

SA0167: Temporary function block instanc.description: The check detects function block instances which are declared as temporary variables. This affects instances which are declared in a method or function or as VAR_TEMP, and therefore are reinitialized in each processing cycle or for each POU call.

SA0168: Unnecessary Assignments.description: Detects assignments to variables which do not have any effect in the code.

SA0169: Ignored outputs.description: Detects the outputs of methods and functions that are not specified when calling the method or function.

SA0170: Address of an output variable sh.description: Detects code locations where the address of an output variable (VAR_OUTPUT, VAR_IN_OUT) of a function block is is determined.

SA0171: Enumerations should have the 'st.description: Detects declarations of enumerations which are not provided with the {attribute 'strict'} attribute.

Lack of Cohesion Of Methods - LCOM.description: Lack of Cohesion Of Methods - LCOM

Number of different used operators - Hal.description: Number of different used operators - Halstead (n1)

Number of different used operands - Hals.description: Number of different used operands - Halstead (n2)

Number of subroutines.description: Number of subroutines in the greater program
